intro: Atriplex acuminata f. subsimplex, commonly known as the smooth leaf saltbush, is a shrub native to arid and semi-arid regions of North America. It is characterized by its succulent, smooth, and often glaucous leaves that help reduce water loss in harsh environments. The plant produces small, greenish flowers in dense, spike-like inflorescences, which are typically wind-pollinated. Its salt-tolerant nature makes it well adapted to saline soils, and it plays a role in stabilizing sandy or disturbed soils. The subspecies subsimplex differs from the typical form by having simpler, less lobed leaves.
